title: Systolic Arrays: A Deep Dive
image_desc: A stylized image of a heart beating, with data streams flowing through arteries.
narration: Welcome! Today, we'll explore systolic arrays, a fascinating type of parallel processor.  Think of it like the rhythmic flow of blood through your arteries – that's the inspiration behind their design.

title: What are Systolic Arrays?
content:
Connected sets of similar integrated circuits.
Hundreds of thousands of transistors on a single chip.
Parallel processors with rhythmic data flow.
Local interconnections for efficient communication.
image_desc: A diagram showing a simplified representation of a systolic array with interconnected processing elements.
narration: Systolic arrays are essentially networks of identical processing units working together.  They pack hundreds of thousands of transistors onto a single chip, enabling massive parallel processing.  The key is the rhythmic flow of data – hence the name, inspired by the heart's systolic phase.  Notice the local interconnections; each processor only talks to its immediate neighbors, simplifying the design.

title: Key Applications
content:
**Column 1: Applications**
Matrix Multiplication
Solving Linear Equations
Bit-Serial Processing
**Column 2: Advantages**
High Efficiency
Simplified Interconnections
Scalability
image_desc: A collage of images representing matrix multiplication, linear equations, and bit-serial processing.
narration: Systolic arrays find applications in various computationally intensive tasks.  We'll focus on matrix multiplication today, but they're also used for solving linear equations and bit-serial processing.  Their advantages include high efficiency due to parallelism, simplified interconnections, and scalability for handling larger problems.

title: Systolic Matrix Multiplication: L = P x Q
content:
P matrix enters from the left.
Q matrix enters from the right.
Partial results of L matrix enter from the bottom.
Intermediate values flow upward.
Final result of L emerges at the top.
image_desc: A diagram illustrating the flow of data (P, Q, and L matrices) through a systolic array during matrix multiplication.  Arrows should clearly show the direction of data movement.
narration: Let's look at matrix multiplication.  We want to compute L = P x Q.  The P matrix enters from the left, Q from the right, and partial results of L from the bottom.  Intermediate values flow upward through the array, and the final result of L emerges at the top.  This rhythmic flow is the essence of systolic processing.

title: A Single Processing Stage
content: (No need to draw in exam of understanding purpose only)
image_desc: A detailed diagram focusing on a single hexagonal processing element within the systolic array, showing the inputs (elements of P and Q) and the output (updated element of L), and the calculation lij = lij + Pik * Qkj.
narration: This diagram shows a single processing stage. An element of the P matrix arrives from the upper left, an element of the Q matrix from the upper right, and a partial result of L from the bottom. The calculation is performed, and the updated L element moves upward to the next stage. This process repeats rhythmically across the entire array.
